title: On the complexity of finding large odd induced subgraphs and odd coloringsWork supported by French projects DEMOGRAPH (ANR-16-CE40-0028), ESIGMA (ANR-17-CE23-0010), and ELIT (ANR-20-CE48-0008-01), the program â€œExploration Japon 2017â€ of the French embassy in Japan, and the JSPS KAKENHI grant number JP18K11157. An extended abstract of this article appeared in the Proceedings of the 46th International Workshop on Graph-Theoretic Concepts in Computer Science (WG), volume 12301 of LNCS, pages 67-79, held online, June 2020. This article is permanently available at https://arxiv.org/abs/2002.06078.

sections.introduction:
Gallai proved, around 60 years ago, that the vertex set of every graph can be partitioned (in polynomial time) into two sets, each of them inducing a subgraph in which all vertices have even degree (cf.Â [33, Exercise 5.19]). Let us call such a subgraph an even subgraph, and an odd subgraph is defined similarly. Hence, every graph GğºG contains an even induced subgraph with at least |Vâ€‹(G)|/2ğ‘‰ğº2|V(G)|/2 vertices. The analogous properties for odd subgraphs seem to be more elusive. For a graph GğºG, let ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œâ€‹(G)ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œğº{\sf mos}(G) and Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(G)subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½ğº\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G) be the order of a largest odd induced subgraph of GğºG and the minimum number of odd induced subgraphs of GğºG that partition Vâ€‹(G)ğ‘‰ğºV(G), respectively. Note that for Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(G)subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½ğº\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G) to be well-defined, each connected component of GğºG must have even order. Concerning the former parameter, the following long-standing â€“and still openâ€“ conjecture is cited as â€œpart of the graph theory folkloreâ€ by CaroÂ : there exists a positive constant cğ‘c such that every graph GğºG without isolated vertices satisfies ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œâ€‹(G)â‰¥câ‹…|Vâ€‹(G)|ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œğºâ‹…ğ‘ğ‘‰ğº{\sf mos}(G)\geq c\cdot|V(G)|. In the following discussion we only consider graphs without isolated vertices. CaroÂ  proved that ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œâ€‹(G)â‰¥(1âˆ’oâ€‹(1))â€‹n/6ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œğº1ğ‘œ1ğ‘›6{\sf mos}(G)\geq(1-o(1))\sqrt{n/6} where n=|Vâ€‹(G)|ğ‘›ğ‘‰ğºn=|V(G)|, and ScottÂ  improved this bound to câ€‹nlogâ¡nğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘›\frac{cn}{\log n} for some c>0ğ‘0c>0. The conjecture has been proved for particular graph classes, such as treesÂ , graphs of bounded chromatic numberÂ , graphs of maximum degree threeÂ , and graphs of tree-width at most twoÂ 7, also obtaining best possible constants. As for the complexity of computing ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œâ€‹(G)ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œğº{\sf mos}(G), Cai and YangÂ  studied, among other problems, two parameterized versions of this problem, and their reductions imply that it is NP-hard. They also prove the NP-hardness of computing the largest size of an even induced subgraph of a graph GğºG, denoted ğ—†ğ–¾ğ—Œâ€‹(G)ğ—†ğ–¾ğ—Œğº{\sf mes}(G). As a follow-up ofÂ , related problems were studied by Cygan et al.Â  and Goyal et al.Â . The parameter Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½\chi_{{\sf odd}}, which we call the odd chromatic number, has attracted much less interest in the literature. To the best of our knowledge, it has only been considered by ScottÂ , who defined it (using a different notation) and proved that the necessary condition discussed above for Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(G)subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½ğº\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G) to be well-defined is also sufficient. He also provided lower and upper bounds on the maximum value of Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(G)subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½ğº\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G) over all nğ‘›n-vertex graphs. In particular, there are graphs GğºG for which Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(G)=Î©â€‹(n)subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½ğºÎ©ğ‘›\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G)=\Omega(\sqrt{n}). Our contribution. In this article we mostly focus on computational aspects of the parameters ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œ{\sf mos} and Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½\chi_{{\sf odd}}. Note that, given a graph GğºG, deciding whether Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(G)â‰¤1subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½ğº1\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G)\leq 1 is trivial. We prove that deciding whether Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(G)â‰¤qsubscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½ğºğ‘\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G)\leq q is NP-complete for every qâ‰¥3ğ‘3q\geq 3 using a reduction from qğ‘q-Coloring. We obtain a dichotomy on the complexity of computing Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½\chi_{{\sf odd}} by showing that deciding whether Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(G)â‰¤2subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½ğº2\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G)\leq 2 can be solved in polynomial time, through a reduction to the existence of a feasible solution to a system of linear equations over GF. Given the NP-hardness of computing both parameters, we are interested in its parameterized complexityÂ  , namely in identifying relevant parameters kğ‘˜k that allow for FPT algorithms, that is, algorithms running in time fâ€‹(k)â‹…nğ’ªâ€‹(1)â‹…ğ‘“ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘›ğ’ª1f(k)\cdot n^{{\mathcal{O}}(1)} for some computable function fğ‘“f. Since the natural parameter, that is, the solution size, for ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œ{\sf mos} has been studied by Cai and YangÂ  (and its dual as well), and for Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½\chi_{{\sf odd}} the problem is para-NP-hard by our hardness results, we rather focus on structural parameters. Two of the most successful ones are definitely tree-width and clique-width, or its parametrically equivalent parameter rank-width introduced by Oum and SeymourÂ 6. This latter parameter is stronger than tree-width, in the sense that graph classes of bounded tree-width also have bounded rank-width; see FigÂ 1. We present algorithms running in time 2ğ’ªâ€‹(ğ—‹ğ—)â‹…nğ’ªâ€‹(1)â‹…superscript2ğ’ªğ—‹ğ—superscriptğ‘›ğ’ª12^{{\mathcal{O}}({\sf rw})}\cdot n^{{\mathcal{O}}(1)} for computing ğ—†ğ–¾ğ—Œâ€‹(G)ğ—†ğ–¾ğ—Œğº{\sf mes}(G) and ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œâ€‹(G)ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œğº{\sf mos}(G) for an nğ‘›n-vertex graph GğºG given along with a decomposition tree of width at most ğ—‹ğ—ğ—‹ğ—{\sf rw}, and an algorithm in time 2ğ’ªâ€‹(qâ‹…ğ—‹ğ—)â‹…nğ’ªâ€‹(1)â‹…superscript2ğ’ªâ‹…ğ‘ğ—‹ğ—superscriptğ‘›ğ’ª12^{{\mathcal{O}}(q\cdot{\sf rw})}\cdot n^{{\mathcal{O}}(1)} for deciding whether Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(G)â‰¤qsubscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½ğºğ‘\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G)\leq q. These algorithms are inspired by the ones of Bui-Xuan et al.Â   to solve Maximum Independent Set parameterized by rank-width and boolean-width, respectively. To the best of our knowledge, our algorithms are the first ones parameterized by rank-width for an NP-hard problem running in time 2oâ€‹(ğ—‹ğ—2)â‹…nğ’ªâ€‹(1)â‹…superscript2ğ‘œsuperscriptğ—‹ğ—2superscriptğ‘›ğ’ª12^{o({\sf rw}^{2})}\cdot n^{{\mathcal{O}}(1)}Â   5 2 3. We also show that the dependency on rank-width of the above algorithms is asymptotically optimal under the Exponential Time Hypothesis (ETH) of Impagliazzo et al.Â 9 8. For this, it suffices to obtain a linear NP-hardness reduction from a problem for which a subexponential algorithm does not exist under the ETH. While our reduction to decide whether Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(G)â‰¤qsubscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½ğºğ‘\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G)\leq q already satisfies this property, the NP-hardness proof of Cai and YangÂ  for computing ğ—†ğ–¾ğ—Œâ€‹(G)ğ—†ğ–¾ğ—Œğº{\sf mes}(G) and ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œâ€‹(G)ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œğº{\sf mos}(G), which is from the Exact Odd Set problemÂ 5, has a quadratic blow-up, so only a lower bound of 2oâ€‹(n)superscript2ğ‘œğ‘›2^{o(\sqrt{n})} can be deduced from it. Motivated by this, we present linear NP-hardness reductions from 2in3-Sat to the problems of computing ğ—†ğ–¾ğ—Œâ€‹(G)ğ—†ğ–¾ğ—Œğº{\sf mes}(G) and ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œâ€‹(G)ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œğº{\sf mos}(G). The reduction itself is not very complicated, but the correctness proof requires some non-trivial arguments111We would like to mention that another NP-hardness proof for computing ğ—†ğ–¾ğ—Œâ€‹(G)ğ—†ğ–¾ğ—Œğº{\sf mes}(G) has very recently appeared onlineÂ 0. The proof uses a chain of reductions from Maximum Cut and, although it also involves a quadratic blow-up, it can be avoided by starting from Maximum Cut restricted to graphs of bounded degree.. Finally, motivated by the complexity of computing these parameters, we obtain two tight bounds on their values. We first prove that for every graph GğºG with all components of even order, Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(G)â‰¤ğ—ğ—â€‹(G)+1subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½ğºğ—ğ—ğº1\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G)\leq{\sf tw}(G)+1, where ğ—ğ—â€‹(G)ğ—ğ—ğº{\sf tw}(G) denotes the tree-width of GğºG. This result improves the best known lower bound on a parameter defined by Hou et al.Â 7 (cf. SectionÂ 5 for the details). On the other hand, we prove that, for every nğ‘›n-vertex graph GğºG such that Vâ€‹(G)ğ‘‰ğºV(G) can be partitioned into two non-empty sets that are complete to each other (i.e., a join), ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œâ€‹(G)â‰¥2â‹…âŒˆnâˆ’24âŒ‰ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—Œğºâ‹…2ğ‘›24{\sf mos}(G)\geq 2\cdot\left\lceil\frac{n-2}{4}\right\rceil.
In particular, this proves the conjecture about the linear size of an odd induced subgraph for cographs, which are the graphs of clique-width two. This adds another graph class to the previous ones for which the conjecture is known to be trueÂ    7. It is interesting to mention that our proof implies that, for a cograph GğºG, Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(G)â‰¤3subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½ğº3\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G)\leq 3, and this bound is also tight. While for cographs, or equivalently P4subscriptğ‘ƒ4P_{4}-free graphs, we have proved that the odd chromatic number is bounded, we also show that it is unbounded for P5subscriptğ‘ƒ5P_{5}-free graphs. Organization. We start with some preliminaries in SectionÂ 2. In SectionÂ 3 we provide the linear NP-hardness reductions and the polynomial-time algorithm for deciding whether Ï‡ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½â€‹(G)â‰¤2subscriptğœ’ğ—ˆğ–½ğ–½ğº2\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G)\leq 2. The FPT algorithms by rank-width are presented in SectionÂ 4, and the tight bounds in SectionÂ 5. We conclude the article in SectionÂ 6 with a number of open problems and research directions. Additional results for related problems discussed in the conclusions can be found in AppendixÂ 0.A.
